lead_paragraph: A jailhouse interview with a German man who joined the Islamic State reveals the workings of a unit whose lieutenants are empowered to plan attacks around the world.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Eric Schmitt from Washington; Franziska Reymann from Bremen; Yousur Al-Hlou from New York; and Maher Samaan from Paris.

headline.print_headline: A Global Network of Killers, Built by a Secretive Branch of ISIS
headline.main: How a Secretive Branch of ISIS Built a Global Network of Killers

snippet: A jailhouse interview with a German man who joined the Islamic State reveals the workings of a unit whose lieutenants are empowered to plan attacks around the world....
abstract: Interviews with captured Islamic State group recruits like Harry Sarfo of Germany reveal extent of operations undertaken by group's intelligence unit, known in Arabic as Emni; part internal police force and part external espionage branch, Emni is dedicated to exporting group's terrorist tactics to foreign nations, particularly European countries.
